newsitem.title: USA: U.S. stocks burst higher, toppling bevy of records.
newsitem.headline: U.S. stocks burst higher, toppling bevy of records.

text.p: The Dow industrials leapt to a record high on Friday after a monthly employment report reinforced investors' positive outlook on the U.S. economy.

The Dow surged 130 points to close unofficially at 7436. The gain, if official, would rank as the sixth largest in point terms in the blue-chip average's history, and shattered the Dow's previous closing high of 7383.41, set on May 27.
The New York Stock Exchange Composite and Standard & Poor's 500 indices also closed at record levels and the Nasdaq Composite ended just a few points shy of its all-time high.
The session began on a nervous note, with bonds tumbling on the release of the employment data.
Investors were initially taken aback by a surprise dip in the unemployment rate to 4.8 percent. The rate was the lowest since October 1973 and raised fears of wage-driven inflation.

But other aspects of the report painted a more confusing picture, showing slower-than-expected job creation in May, a steep upward revision to April's new jobs figure and a moderate level of wage increases for May.
Taken as a whole, analysts said the data showed the economy remains in an ideal mode for the stock market.
"The report basically said we are in an economy that is performing extremely well without any acceleration of inflation," said Peter Cardillo, director of research at Westfalia Investments.

Bonds, which initially tumbled after release of the report, eventually changed course and staged a powerful rally of their own, driving the yield on the benchmark long bond down to 6.78 percent, its lowest since February 28.
Analysts said the bond market's gains were particularly encouraging and, if sustained, could lay the groundwork for an extended stock market rally.
"I think it's pretty clear this is not a one-day wonder," said Peter Canelo, U.S. equity strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter.
"There's a solid case being made in the market that there's no inflation risk," he said. "As long as bonds are settling down, this market is going higher."

Analysts also noted that the strong growth-stable inflation picture appeared to attract renewed attention from investors abroad, particularly Europe, where questions mount daily about the political and economic outlook.

"The European monetary union looks like it's having trouble and there is fighting in Germany over their gold policy and uncertainty in France about the political situation," said Charles Pradilla, market analyst at Cowen and Co.
"Here we are with a strong economy and no sign of inflation troubles," he said, "so it's not surprising that our assets look attractive."

Financial stocks surged, boosted by the firm bond market. Dow components J.P. Morgan & Co Inc added 2-3/4 to 111-1/2, American Express Co rose 2-3/8 to 71-3/4 and Travelers Group Inc rose 1-3/4 to 57-7/8.
The favorable growth outlook implied by the strong economic picuture lifted tech stocks. Microsoft Corp climbed 3-1/2 to 124-1/16 and International Business Machines Corp gained 2-3/4 to 85-5/8.
Drug stocks also rallied, with Pfizer Inc up 4-1/8 to 107, Eli Lilly and Co up four to 97-1/8 and Warner-Lambert Co up four to 102.

First Brands Corp fell 3-3/8 to 22-5/8. The company warned its fiscal fourth-quarter earnings would fall short of analysts' estimates and said profits could remain under pressure through the next two quarters.
Storage Dimensions Inc fell 3-15/16 to 6-5/16. Late Thursday, the company warned that its second-quarter results would be below expectations.
The S&P 500 index rose 14.58 points to 858.01, a record.
The Nasdaq Composite gained 14.79 points to 1404.84.
((-- Wall Street desk, 212-859-1730))
